chapter.fullItemName: Scenario: UTI  (no visible haematuria, not pregnant or catheterized)
chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: UTI — (no visible haematuria, not pregnant or catheterized)
chapter.summary: Covers the management of a suspected urinary tract infection (UTI) in women who do not have haematuria, and who are not pregnant or catheterized. It includes the management of treatment failure following initial antibiotic treatment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage acute lower urinary tract infection without haematuria in a woman who is not pregnant or catheterized?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Arrange urgent assessment in secondary care if there are any features of serious or systemic illness such as sepsis.
  • Advise the woman on self-care measures:
    • Simple analgesia such as paracetamol (or if preferred and suitable, ibuprofen) can be used for pain relief.
      • For further information, see the CKS topics on Analgesia - mild-to-moderate pain and NSAIDs - prescribing issues.
    • Encourage intake of enough fluids to avoid dehydration.
      • Do not recommend cranberry products or urine alkalinising agents.
    • Patient information leaflets ‘Treating your infection – Urinary tract infection (UTI)’ and ‘Urinary tract infections: A leaflet for older adults and carers’ are available from the Royal Collage of General Practice website.
  • Consider the need for antibiotics depending on severity of symptoms, risk of complications, and previous urine culture results and antibiotic use.
    • If prescribing an immediate antibiotic — treat according to sensitivities from recent urine culture (if available), otherwise treat empirically taking account of local antimicrobial resistance patterns:
      • For first choice, consider prescribing:
        • Nitrofurantoin 100mg modified-release twice a day for 3 days (if eGFR ≥45ml/minute) or
        • Trimethoprim 200mg twice a day for 3 days (if low risk of resistance).
      • For second choice (if there is no improvement in symptoms when first-choice antibiotic is taken for at least 48 hours or if first-choice is unsuitable) consider prescribing:
        • Nitrofurantoin 100mg modified-release twice a day for 3 days (if eGFR ≥45ml/minute and not used as first-choice) or
        • Pivmecillinam (a penicillin) 400mg initial dose, then 200mg three times a day for a total of 3 days or
        • Fosfomycin 3g single dose sachet.
      • A summary of the National Institute for Health and Care (NICE) antimicrobial prescribing guidance is available on the NICE website.
    • If prescribing a delayed (back-up) antibiotic — advise the woman to start antibiotics if symptoms do not improve within 48 hours or worsen at any time.
      • A delayed script can be considered instead of immediate antibiotics if symptoms are mild and there are no risk factors for complicated infection.
  • Advise all women to seek urgent medical review if:
    • Symptoms worsen rapidly or significantly at any time or fail to improve within 48 hours of starting antibiotics — consider the possibility of alternative or serious diagnoses such as pyelonephritis or sepsis.
    • Send a urine sample for culture and susceptibility testing (if not already done) and consider treatment with another agent (as described above) while awaiting sensitivities.
  • If a urine sample has been sent for culture and sensitivity testing:
    • Review the choice of antibiotic when results are available.
    • Change the antibiotic according to susceptibility results if bacteria are resistant and symptoms are not already improving — use narrow-spectrum antibiotics if possible.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on the management of women with lower UTI (no haematuria, not pregnant or catheterized) are based on the clinical guidelines Quick reference guide for primary care: for consultation and local adaptation [PHE, 2017], Urological infections [EAU, 2018], Urinary tract infections (lower): antimicrobial prescribing NG109 [NICE, 2018d], UK standards for microbiological investigations. Investigation of urine [PHE, 2018a] and Primary care empirical urinary tract infection treatment guidelines [All Wales Medicines Strategy Group, 2018] and expert opinion in review articles [BMJ Best Practice, 2018b].

Admission

Clinical guidelines from Public Health England (PHE) [PHE, 2017] and the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) [NICE, 2018d] highlight the importance of prompt recognition and treatment of serious illness such as sepsis.

Self-care measures

Recommendations on use of simple analgesia and maintaining adequate hydration are based on clinical guidance from NICE [NICE, 2018d] and PHE [PHE, 2017].

  • NICE found no evidence to support the use of cranberry products and urine alkalinising agents in treatment of lower UTI.
Treatment with antibiotics

The recommendations on choice of antibiotic for use in lower UTI are based on the NICE clinical guideline Urinary tract infections (lower): antimicrobial prescribing NG109 [NICE, 2018d].

  • Choice of antibiotic:
    • The NICE recommendations on first and second line antibiotics are based on evidence, clinical experience and resistance data. The NICE guideline committee acknowledges that prescribers in the UK may be less familiar with second-choice antibiotics such as pivmecillinam or fosfomycin — these antibiotics are often used in other European countries [EAU, 2018].
    • Trimethoprim is recommended as an alternative first choice where there is low risk of resistance — the risk of resistance may be lower if trimethoprim has not been used in the preceding 3 months, recent urine culture suggests susceptibility (but trimethoprim was not used), and in younger people in areas where local data suggest resistance is low. A higher risk of resistance may be more likely with recent use and in older women in residential facilities [NICE, 2018d].
    • The European Association of Urology [EAU, 2018] recommend fosfomycin, pivmecillinam and nitrofurantoin as drugs of first choice based on susceptibility patterns in Europe. Use of alternative antimicrobials (such as trimethoprim alone or combined with a sulphonamide) are advised as drugs of first choice only in areas where known resistance rates for E. coli are less than 20%.
    • NICE guidance [NICE, 2018d] states that prescribers should take into account local antimicrobial resistance patterns as these vary by area.
  • Duration of antibiotic treatment:
    • NICE [NICE, 2018d] recommend a 3-day course of treatment in non-pregnant women with uncomplicated lower UTI — this is based on evidence that a 3 day course is as effective as a 5–10 day course and is associated with significantly fewer adverse events.
  • Delayed script/back-up antibiotics
    • NICE guidance states that in most cases antibiotics are needed for treatment of lower UTI. However, in some non-pregnant women, acute uncomplicated lower UTI can be self-limiting and delay of antibiotic treatment with provision of a back-up prescription may lead to symptom resolution without antibiotic treatment [NICE, 2018d].
When to seek review

The recommendation on advising all women to seek urgent medical review if symptoms worsen rapidly or significantly at any time or fail to improve within 48 hours of starting antibiotics is based on guidance from NICE [NICE, 2018d] and PHE [PHE, 2017].

  • Non-response may be due to a resistant organism and the woman may require further investigation and treatment — a urine sample should be sent to identify sensitivities and microbiology advice sought if a multi-resistant organism is cultured [HPA, 2011].
  • Failure to culture bacteria in the urine of a woman with cystitis may be a false negative result but the possibility of an alternative cause for symptoms is significantly increased and should be considered.
Follow up of culture results

Guidance from NICE [NICE, 2018d] and PHE [PHE, 2017; PHE, 2018a] agree that choice of antibiotic should be reviewed when culture and sensitivity results become available.
